etymologies: early 17th century: from Latin curulis, from currus ‘chariot’ (in which the chief magistrate was conveyed to the seat of office), from currere ‘to run’

definitions: denoting or relating to the authority exercised by the senior magistrates in ancient Rome, chiefly the consul and praetor, who were entitled to use the sella curulis (‘curule seat,’ a kind of folding chair).
shortDefinitions: denoting or relating to authority exercised by senior magistrates in ancient Rome, chiefly consul and praetor
